channel.title: Text Searcher
channel.description:
I've made a program in vb.net that searches for text that you ask it to search for.
Like: If you enter 'sendMessage' it will say in what .java files you can find it.
V1.0 download: Click [url=http://www.mediafire.com/?z4jzejzmut3]here[/url] to download it. It's 19.5kb.
Pic: [img]http://i47.photobucket.com/albums/f168/nevercme/TextSearcher.jpg[/img]
---UPDATED--- TextSearcherV1.1 Pic: [img]http://i47.photobucket.com/albums/f168/nevercme/textsearcher2.jpg[/img] What's new?: -You can see on which line it occurs -You can see the line containing the match -You can choose to search in .java, .txt or in both file extensions
V1.1 download: Click [url=http://www.mediafire.com/?zmdimk2jzim]here[/url] to download it. It's 23kb.

item.title: Text Searcher
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“PeeHPee, post:28, topic:341378”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=437776.msg3221289#msg3221289 date=1275188979]

[quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=437776.msg3221210#msg3221210 date=1275182548]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=437776.msg3220764#msg3220764 date=1275159395]

[quote author=PeeHPee link=topic=437776.msg3220763#msg3220763 date=1275159315]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=437776.msg3220759#msg3220759 date=1275159102]

What do you mean with ‘regex’?
I’m not familiar with that word =
I looked it up on wikipedia and I found that it stands for ‘Regular Expressions’.
But I don’t really understand what it means.
Could you give me an example?
[/quote]Rofl, Regular Expression. Google it.

That’s what regex is…
[/quote]I know… he was asking me what it meant, so I told him.

i bet you don’t even know what regex is (i’m not talking about the definition, i mean what it does…)
[/quote]I made a regex search feature for my mass replace… and you think I don’t know what it means?
[/quote]there’s a difference between knowing how to execute regex and actually creating a pattern
[/quote]Yes I can create patterns to. (Which is the easy part…)

\d, \D, etc, it’s not complicated…

The hardest part of making patters is creating custom classes, which is not hard either.

sorry but \d is a character class not a regular expression.[/quote]I’m pretty sure you could compile that into a matcher. It’s a regex.

[quote=“abraham2119, post:29, topic:341378”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=437776.msg3221289#msg3221289 date=1275188979]

[quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=437776.msg3221210#msg3221210 date=1275182548]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=437776.msg3220764#msg3220764 date=1275159395]

[quote author=PeeHPee link=topic=437776.msg3220763#msg3220763 date=1275159315]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=437776.msg3220759#msg3220759 date=1275159102]

[quote author=The Soul link=topic=437776.msg3220741#msg3220741 date=1275158005]

What do you mean with ‘regex’?
I’m not familiar with that word =
I looked it up on wikipedia and I found that it stands for ‘Regular Expressions’.
But I don’t really understand what it means.
Could you give me an example?
[/quote]Rofl, Regular Expression. Google it.

That’s what regex is…
[/quote]I know… he was asking me what it meant, so I told him.

i bet you don’t even know what regex is (i’m not talking about the definition, i mean what it does…)
[/quote]I made a regex search feature for my mass replace… and you think I don’t know what it means?
[/quote]there’s a difference between knowing how to execute regex and actually creating a pattern
[/quote]Yes I can create patterns to. (Which is the easy part…)

\d, \D, etc, it’s not complicated…

The hardest part of making patters is creating custom classes, which is not hard either.
[/quote]those are predefined character classes, i’m talking about a pattern making use of lookaheads/lookbehinds, group capturing, etc, not that standard pile of wank[/quote]one(?=two)three where ‘two’ and ‘three’ match where ‘one’ ends? Is that what you mean? That kind of stuff?

Read full topic

item.title: Text Searcher
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“VbCoder, post:18, topic:341378”]Well, I probably did it whole different then Davidi2’s Mass Replace thingy and the ZFileSearcher

I let the command prompt save all the ‘*.java’ files in the folder where the TextSearcher is in in a file called ‘files.txt’.

Shell("cmd /c dir *.java /b > files.txt", vbHide)

And then…

Sub Read() Dim Read As New System.IO.StreamReader("files.txt") Do Until Read.EndOfStream Main.txtJavaFiles.Text = Read.ReadLine Dim Read2 As New System.IO.StreamReader(Main.txtJavaFiles.Text) Dim LineNr As String = 0 Do Until Read2.EndOfStream LineNr = LineNr + 1 Dim Line As String = Read2.ReadLine If Line.Contains(Main.txtSearch.Text) Then Main.txtFound.Text = (Main.txtFound.Text & vbNewLine & "Found in: " & Main.txtJavaFiles.Text & " (line " & LineNr & ")" & vbNewLine & " " & Line) Else End If Loop Loop End Sub[/quote]If you want it to be functional (worth downloading at all), you need to add some more features. Like Silab said, regex, but things like choosing which files you want, and case sensitivity options would help.

Read full topic

item.title: Text Searcher
item.dc:creator: @VbCoder VbCoder
item.description:
@VbCoder wrote:

Well, I probably did it whole different then Davidi2’s Mass Replace thingy and the ZFileSearcher

I let the command prompt save all the ‘*.java’ files in the folder where the TextSearcher is in in a file called ‘files.txt’.

Shell("cmd /c dir *.java /b > files.txt", vbHide)

And then…

Sub Read() Dim Read As New System.IO.StreamReader("files.txt") Do Until Read.EndOfStream Main.txtJavaFiles.Text = Read.ReadLine Dim Read2 As New System.IO.StreamReader(Main.txtJavaFiles.Text) Dim LineNr As String = 0 Do Until Read2.EndOfStream LineNr = LineNr + 1 Dim Line As String = Read2.ReadLine If Line.Contains(Main.txtSearch.Text) Then Main.txtFound.Text = (Main.txtFound.Text & vbNewLine & "Found in: " & Main.txtJavaFiles.Text & " (line " & LineNr & ")" & vbNewLine & " " & Line) Else End If Loop Loop End Sub

Read full topic

item.title: Text Searcher
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

Mayby even a label around the textbox that counts how many times it found the entry?

Not required, or even too helpful, but i can give you the idea if you need to be more specific. For example, if you only got 200 entries, it might take a little bit, but you will find it. Yet, if you got around 800+ entries, its a good idea to be a bit more specific.

Read full topic
